body.name: The Last Restaurant in Paris: Completely heartbreaking and gripping World War 2 fiction

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #12,996 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #14 in Jewish Historical Fiction #134 in Women's Literary Fiction #162 in Women's Historical Fiction

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024
reviews.reviewText: A book of war, treachery and showing we never know what we are capable of until we reach our breaking point.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Loved the heroine and her grandmere! The way food was made to love and sustain friends and neighbors in horrendous times connects across the ages!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Whenever I read historical fiction, the WWII era is my favorite story line to visit.The Last Restaurant in Paris takes place during the WWII German occupation in Paris. It is told in a past/present format. We ultimately follow the story of Marianne. She is one of the few Parisans that successfully opened up a restaurant during war time. Her motivation to do so was her own secret and that secret unfolds as the story goes on.The story telling was captivating and I didn’t want to put this one down. I highly recommend this one if WWII historical fiction is your favorite.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I loved this novel! The story begins as a family mystery which seems like Sabine will never find the answers to. As she investigates further she discovers so much about her grandmother and her actions during WW2 in occupied France. It was a beautiful story with almost tangible characters. Well done!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I thought this was an interesting WW2 story with interesting twists on life in the country growing up before and during the war and the importance of friendships and family.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Interesting WWII period novel
reviews.reviewText: A sad story, but an enjoyable read overall. I though the author spent too much time describing the background of Elodie Clairmont. I found that boring. The story was about a restaurant in paris, but half the story was about this girl in a country town and in England. Then only in the last several chapters she changes her name and proceeds with the story. The subplot seemed longer than the main plot.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Easily one of the best books I've ever read! Drawn in from the first page, I powered through this story of courage, loss, heartache and triumph. Could barely put it down, and when I had to be away from it...all I could think about was getting back to it. This book proves we never knowsomeone's true story at first glance. Cried more than once!! Read this powerful story...you won't regret it!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars EAT YOUR HEART OUT, and DIE!
reviews.reviewText: Graham has penned a wonderful family saga and captured a new reader!Using multiple family stories she finally ties them altogether to illustrate the span of of the tragedy of wars and the effects it had on the individual characters. Each dealt with their personal losses in different ways, but in the end each gained and shared their strength to strengthen others.She captured the history of the times in language, dress, food and cooking with limited wartime rations as well as the extravagances of the German troops during the occupation. But, in the end the Liberty- Loving French served their country with their skills, talents, and limited resources. Viva la France!A great story based on good research, great dialog, and character development as characters grew from childhood to adulthood, and finally old age. Their troubles fertilized their strength and their character as if they became their own vineyards and gardens. Their French roots grew deeper in their rocky soil as their commitment to The Resistance began to flower and to feed the future generations.

A woman with a background of love and loss. The last loss being the murder of her husband by a Nazi officer. Placing her daughter in the care of her nun friend, she leaves Provence and opens a restaurant in Paris seemingly a collaborator. She actually helps the resistance, learning information from her Nazi customers and passing it on, waiting for a chance to take ultimate revenge on the officer she knows was the one that shot and killed her husband.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This is one of the best books I’ve read, I couldn’t put it down. I was gripped from the first pages and felt like I was transported back in time. A must read

reviews.reviewTitle: Another novel highlighting life under the Nazis!
reviews.reviewText: A heart warming story about how dangerous and troubling life was every day under the Nazi occupation. It is amazing how people learned their own ways of survival and how they coped with the everyday stress of wondering whether their loved ones were alive or not.
Enjoyed reading this book with its war era turns of events.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 8, 2023
